poem:
### The Gamble

Silver coins spin—  
hissed disputes echo  
in hallowed halls,  
while paper dreams  
flutter and fall,  
clad in manifest errors,  
rich voices call—  
a gamble for gold,  
the cost unknown,  
silent hands clasp,  
grip thin air—  
where luck  
or folly  
dare to share.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Richard Desmond legal action over National Lottery award to begin at high court The media billionaire Richard Desmond will begin a bitter courtroom battle with the Gambling Commission this week that could cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of pounds in a row over the licence to run the National Lottery. Northern & Shell and The New Lottery Company (TNLC), owned by Desmond, are suing the gambling regulator for up to £1.3bn, alleging “manifest errors” in". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
